clinical_study.brief_title: Safety and Efficacy Study of the Draeger Babylog VN500 Device in HFOV Mode in VLBW Neonates
clinical_study.official_title: A Clinical Study to Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of the Infinity Acute Care System Workstation Neonatal Care Babylog VN500 Device in High Frequency Oscillatory Ventilation (HFOV) Mode in Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW) Neonates

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the safety and effectiveness of the Babylog VN500 in high frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) mode as a method for treating very low birth weight (VLBW) neonates requiring invasive respiratory support in the treatment of respiratory distress.

detailed_description.textblock: Results from this single-arm, multi-center clinical study are intended to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Babylog VN500 device in high frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) mode in very low birth weight (VLBW) neonates of 23 to 30 weeks' gestational age (400 g to 1200 g, inclusive) with documented respiratory distress requiring invasive respiratory support. The safety will be determined by evaluating the rate of subjects alive at Day 32 and free of Grade III/IV intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) or cystic periventricular leukomalacia. Evaluation of the Alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient 12 hours after start of ventilation will account for the effectiveness.

primary_outcome.measure: Alive and free from Grade III/IV intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and cystic periventricular leukomalacia (PVL)

primary_outcome.time_frame: 12 hours after onset of HFOV treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Freedom from study-defined serious adverse events
secondary_outcome.description: Events related to the Condition of Prematurity and the requirement for invasive respiratory suppport
malfunction of the investigational device necessitating removal of a neonate to another Ventilation mode or ventilator
Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development III

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of partial carbon dioxide pressure (PaCO2)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2, 6, 12, 24, 36 and 48 hours after onset of HFOV treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of time and amount that the carbon dioxide Tension values are outside the target range of 40 to 55 mmHg

secondary_outcome.measure: Relationship between tidal volume high frequency (Vthf) set and Vthf observed
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 2, 6, 12, 24, 36 and 48 hours and once daily after onset of HFOV treatment
secondary_outcome.description: difference between mean Vthf set and mean Vthf observed

secondary_outcome.measure: Stability of Vthf observed and carbon dioxide diffusion (DCO2) coefficient monitoring during high frequency oscillation over time

secondary_outcome.description: Need for any oxygen or positive airway pressure

secondary_outcome.measure: Length and Type of Respiratory Support
secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 14 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: invasive ventilator support, supplemental oxygen, positive pressure support

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 14 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: survival with and without the need for supplemental oxygen

clinical_study.condition: Respiratory Distress Syndrome In Premature Infants

arm_group.description: Subjects will be treated with HFOV provided by the Babylog VN500 - the investigational device - for up to 14 days.

intervention.description: Treatment with high frequency oscillatory ventilation with investigational device for up to 14 days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Gestational Age between 23 to 30 weeks; within first 4 days of life
- very low birth weight between 400 g and 1200 g, inclusive
- 5-minute Apgar score >3
- documented respiratory distress requiring invasive respiratory Support
- A priori: primary intention for either HFOV or high-frequency jet ventilation OR Severity of Illness: mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen of ≥ 0.25% and a mean airway pressure of ≥ 7 cm H2O, more than 2 hours after an initial dose of surfactant required and clinical care team believes that treatment with HFOV is indicated
- anticipated availability of investigational device at the study center before screening for enrollment
- written informed consent to participate in the study provided by a parent or legal guardian
Exclusion Criteria:
- anticipation to require intubation and mechanical ventilation for less than 12 hours
- previous exposure to any mechanical ventilation for ≥ 96 hours before planned HFOV treatment
- obvious chromosomal or major congenital abnormalities involving the respiratory tract or upper airway
- known congenital heart disease, excluding Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), ventricular-septal defect, or atrial-septal defect
- pre-existing air leak, including pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum, pneumopericardium, or extensive bilateral Pulmonary Interstitial Emphysema (PIE)
- severe metabolic acidosis with a base deficit of ≥ 15 before planned HFOV treatment
- severe hypotension (a mean blood pressure more than 2 standard deviations below the mean neonate's birth weight despite a total combined dose of dopamine, dobutamine, or both, of 20 µg(kg/min)
- moribund subject not expected to survive, or a subject in whom there is a decision to limit care
- currently receiving or previous treatment with inhaled nitric oxide
- currently receiving or previous treatment with corticosteroids specifically for BPD prevention
- evidence of severe sepsis (neutropenia, severe hypotension, shock)
- evidence of Nectrotising Enterocolitis (NEC), defined as Modified Bell's Stage II or greater
- documented Grade III/IV intraventricular hemorrhage
- current enrollment in another Investigational Device Exemption or Investigational New Drug clinical study where treatment, testing, or follow-up may interfere with the results
